content.raw: That sounds totally reasonable to me, especially if this is an existing practice in other industries.
content.html: That sounds totally reasonable to me, especially if this is an existing practice in other industries.

content.raw:
I also am not a security expert. This is the first step towards multifaceted security. Encryption will come next, and part of that could be encrypted configuration information. We will still get to point of having both the secret information and the key to unlock the information on the same machine. Any extra security beyond that would be in the hands of the user.

As a point of reference, plain text environment variables are commonly used in web applications. Security of this data is placed on the user. Deployment services, like AWS, usually support hiding/securing environment variables.
content.html:
I also am not a security expert. This is the first step towards multifaceted security. Encryption will come next, and part of that could be encrypted configuration information. We will still get to point of having both the secret information and the key to unlock the information on the same machine. Any extra security beyond that would be in the hands of the user.

As a point of reference, plain text environment variables are commonly used in web applications. Security of this data is placed on the user. Deployment services, like AWS, usually support hiding/securing environment variables.

content.raw:
I got rid of an unused argument warning. b8229eb

On a higher level, I'm wondering how secure it is to store username and password information as plaintext environment variables. I certainly see the convenience of that, and I don't have a better alternative to recommend off the top of my head, but my understanding is that it presents an exploitable security vulnerability (granted, the malicious code would have to be running on the authorized computer to exploit it).

I don't have any objection to accepting this PR as it is, but I'm wondering if we have any long-term plans to offer alternative (potentially more secure) ways of managing authentication information? But maybe ironclad security for `ign-transport` isn't critical enough to justify the development effort.

Disclaimer: I have no background whatsoever in security or authentication practices.
content.html:
I got rid of an unused argument warning. b8229eb

On a higher level, I'm wondering how secure it is to store username and password information as plaintext environment variables. I certainly see the convenience of that, and I don't have a better alternative to recommend off the top of my head, but my understanding is that it presents an exploitable security vulnerability (granted, the malicious code would have to be running on the authorized computer to exploit it).

I don't have any objection to accepting this PR as it is, but I'm wondering if we have any long-term plans to offer alternative (potentially more secure) ways of managing authentication information? But maybe ironclad security for ign-transport isn't critical enough to justify the development effort.

Disclaimer: I have no background whatsoever in security or authentication practices.

content.raw:
I agree that magic number are bad. This is magic number defined by ZeroMq: http://api.zeromq.org/4-0:zmq-setsockopt

Placing this number here gives it context and reduces the scope of the magic number. I added additional documentation and used a more verbose name: f865008.

I'm not sure moving this parameter to a different location will change much.
content.html:
I agree that magic number are bad. This is magic number defined by ZeroMq: http://api.zeromq.org/4-0:zmq-setsockopt

Placing this number here gives it context and reduces the scope of the magic number. I added additional documentation and used a more verbose name: f865008.

I'm not sure moving this parameter to a different location will change much.

content.raw: Are you sure you see this problem on this branch? This branch doesn't touch cmake, except for the inclusion of tests in `test/integration/CMakeLists.txt`. I'm also unable to reproduce this problem.
content.html: Are you sure you see this problem on this branch? This branch doesn't touch cmake, except for the inclusion of tests in test/integration/CMakeLists.txt. I'm also unable to reproduce this problem.

content.raw:
I get the following errors when trying to configure cmake for this branch:

```
CMake Error: File /api.in does not exist.
CMake Error at doc/CMakeLists.txt:7 (configure_file):
  configure_file Problem configuring file


CMake Error: File /tutorials.in does not exist.
CMake Error at doc/CMakeLists.txt:10 (configure_file):
  configure_file Problem configuring file
```

It looks like it's trying to use the variable `IGNITION_CMAKE_DOXYGEN_DIR` which gets set by `ign-cmake`, but this branch isn't set up to use `ign-cmake` yet, so that variable is unavailable. As a result, `${IGNITION_CMAKE_DOXYGEN_DIR}/api.in` deteriorates to `/api.in` which of course cannot be found.

Merging in the [`ign-cmake`](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/239/use-ign-cmake/diff) branch to this one should help with this issue.
content.html:
I get the following errors when trying to configure cmake for this branch:

CMake Error: File /api.in does not exist.
CMake Error at doc/CMakeLists.txt:7 (configure_file):
  configure_file Problem configuring file


CMake Error: File /tutorials.in does not exist.
CMake Error at doc/CMakeLists.txt:10 (configure_file):
  configure_file Problem configuring file

It looks like it's trying to use the variable IGNITION_CMAKE_DOXYGEN_DIR which gets set by ign-cmake, but this branch isn't set up to use ign-cmake yet, so that variable is unavailable. As a result, ${IGNITION_CMAKE_DOXYGEN_DIR}/api.in deteriorates to /api.in which of course cannot be found.

Merging in the ign-cmake branch to this one should help with this issue.

content.raw: I think we should probably avoid magic numbers. Can we define an authoritative header const, enum, or macro to hold this `1` value and give it semantic meaning?
content.html: I think we should probably avoid magic numbers. Can we define an authoritative header const, enum, or macro to hold this 1 value and give it semantic meaning?

content.raw:
`(warning) Member variable 'NodeSharedPrivate::accessControlThread' is not initialized in the constructor.`

Alternatively to null initialize it, you can declare it as a plain `std::thread`, as we're doing in `Discovery.hh`.
content.html:
(warning) Member variable 'NodeSharedPrivate::accessControlThread' is not initialized in the constructor.

Alternatively to null initialize it, you can declare it as a plain std::thread, as we're doing in Discovery.hh.

The same comment applies to other helper functions that use a raw pointer to a `socket_t`.
